messages.subject: RE: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Most up to date Hurricane watch
messages.msgSnippet: From what I understand, they re evacuating it for the first time but it doesn t matter who is staying there, no one is allowed to travel to Galveston. Holly
messages.messageBody:
From what I understand, they're evacuating it for the first time but it doesn't matter who is staying there, no one is allowed to travel to Galveston.

Holly

Robyn Coburn <dezigna@...> wrote:
They should probably just go up to UTMB. Otherwise they will now be caught
in the same traffic snarl that you mentioned, Holly.

My father is in charge of evacuating patients and managing the services for
non-evacuees (if moving would kill them) and on going emergency running of
the hospital at UTMB - one of the safest, most high-tech complex of
buildings in the region. It was designed and built to withstand a Cat 5, as
is the only other skyscraper on the island, a bank.

All the relevant staff were ordered to the hospital on Wednesday, and to be
ready to stay there for a week. So he has put up the shutters at his home
and gone in.

Robyn L. Coburn

messages.subject: RE: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Most up to date Hurricane watch
messages.messageBody:
<<< There might be a local radio station or two but Galveston gets its news
from Houston stations. Galveston is pretty empty though the news did have
some homeless people complaining about not having transportation off the
island despite the city providing buses for anyone who wanted them.>>>>

They should probably just go up to UTMB. Otherwise they will now be caught
in the same traffic snarl that you mentioned, Holly.

My father is in charge of evacuating patients and managing the services for
non-evacuees (if moving would kill them) and on going emergency running of
the hospital at UTMB - one of the safest, most high-tech complex of
buildings in the region. It was designed and built to withstand a Cat 5, as
is the only other skyscraper on the island, a bank.

All the relevant staff were ordered to the hospital on Wednesday, and to be
ready to stay there for a week. So he has put up the shutters at his home
and gone in.

Robyn L. Coburn

messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Most up to date Hurricane watch
messages.msgSnippet: There might be a local radio station or two but Galveston gets its news from Houston stations.  Galveston is pretty empty though the news did have some
messages.messageBody:
There might be a local radio station or two but Galveston gets its news from Houston stations. Galveston is pretty empty though the news did have some homeless people complaining about not having transportation off the island despite the city providing buses for anyone who wanted them.

Holly

tuckervill2@... wrote:
_http://www.ktrh.com/audio.html_ (http://www.ktrh.com/audio.html)

Informative Houston station doing hurricane coverage.

There's not much about Galveston--but I couldn't find a station there that
was doing live coverage.

Karen

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Most up to date Hurricane watch
messages.msgSnippet: Also, I ve been listening to _www.wwl.com_ (http://www.wwl.com)   (am station in New Orleans) online.  They re on all the time taking calls  and getting
messages.messageBody:
Also, I've been listening to _www.wwl.com_ (http://www.wwl.com) (am station
in New Orleans) online. They're on all the time taking calls and getting
information out. I am sure there are Texas stations that are in full emergency
mode already. I find this to be more informative and satisfying than CNN or
blogs.

After I read my mail I am going to hunt up a Houston or Galveston station
and see what I can hear. I'll post one if I find one.

Karen


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Most up to date Hurricane watch
messages.msgSnippet: Oh boy!  That s frightening.  The Perfect Storm. Hurricanes have always been my favirute natural disaster. I used to love watching films of them in science
messages.messageBody:
Oh boy! That's frightening. The Perfect Storm.

Hurricanes have always been my favirute natural disaster. I used to love watching films of them in science class or on documentaries. This will be my thrid one but the other two were merely a Cat. 3 and 2. There was lots of excitement and very little danger where I was staying. When Alicia hit, the eye passed right over. What an experience! The energy is just incredible and you realize that man really has no control over what the earth does. It's very humbling.

Holly

Robyn Coburn <dezigna@...> wrote:
<<<< I tried to call but got a recording about curcuits being busy. We
would like to come to your house if we need to. We're still waiting to
decide until we hear the evening news. My daughter said they are
downgrading her and she'll probably be a catagory 3. It was so much easier
without kids. I would easily take the risk.>>>>

http://www.wunderground.com/blog/SteveGregory/show.html

This is the best source for information about it according to my dh - better
(more comprehensive for the public) than the advisory at the NWS. These
folks are some meteorologists who analyze all the data, load it into their
own supercomputers, and then put out their opinion in a measured, not
sensationalized, manner. Plus it is very much up to the minute. (Downgrading
to a category 3 does not sound likely at the last input.)

Scroll down the page for the latest satellite picks and computer models.

Robyn L. Coburn

messages.subject: Oops!  I meant to send that privately! [was: Any unschoolers in San Antonio or Austin...]
messages.msgSnippet: It s *so* crazy here.  Please disregard the last message unless you want to call and give messages of hope and support! ;-) Holly Kimberly Viducich
messages.messageBody:
It's *so* crazy here. Please disregard the last message unless you want to call and give messages of hope and support! ;-)

Holly

Kimberly Viducich <kvid@...> wrote:
if there are no offers from san anton or austin we're
in Kingwood and will most likely stay. our number is
281.495.4608. There will b a school near us to
evacuate if it gets too bad.

Kimberly and Jeff

--- Holly Furgason wrote:

> Who are able to put up a family of unschooling Rita
> evacuees from
> Houston? We are trying to figure out where to go
> but money is really
> tight. All the credit cards went to plywood etc.
>
> There are 6 of us- me, dh, 17, 15, 11 yod and 20
> yos. We also have
> animals but will be bringing cages and crates.
> We're lots of fun and
> can train your dogs, show your kids how to do
> karate, juggle,
> entertain you with comdey, dancing, singing or we
> can babysit, weed
> your garden, paint your house or do your dishes in
> exchange. :-) We
> will have our own food and one tent.
>
> Please email me directly at unschooler@... if
> you can help.
>
> Holly
> Unschooling T-shirts and more!
> http://www.cafepress.com/2cool4school
>
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Any unschoolers in San Antonio or Austin...
messages.msgSnippet: Kimberly, I tried to call but got a recording about curcuits being busy.  We would like to come to your house if we need to.  We re still waiting to decide
messages.messageBody:
Kimberly,

I tried to call but got a recording about curcuits being busy. We would like to come to your house if we need to. We're still waiting to decide until we hear the evening news. My daughter said they are downgrading her and she'll probably be a catagory 3. It was so much easier without kids. I would easily take the risk.

My number is (713)880-1474, cell is (832)527-7291.

Holly

tessags@... wrote:
Hi again, Holly!

We're just watching the news - whew - unbelieveable! Seriously, I'm not well known on the group as my son is not yet one, but I've been a member for quite awhile now. We'd love to have you all if you need a place!! We've got a modest house, an air mattress, pull out couch, floor space, hot showers, plenty of ice & a trampoline in the back yard!

Tess

messages.subject: Any unschoolers in San Antonio or Austin...
messages.msgSnippet: Who are able to put up a family of unschooling Rita evacuees from Houston?  We are trying to figure out where to go but money is really tight.  All the credit
messages.messageBody:
Who are able to put up a family of unschooling Rita evacuees from
Houston? We are trying to figure out where to go but money is really
tight. All the credit cards went to plywood etc.

There are 6 of us- me, dh, 17, 15, 11 yod and 20 yos. We also have
animals but will be bringing cages and crates. We're lots of fun and
can train your dogs, show your kids how to do karate, juggle,
entertain you with comdey, dancing, singing or we can babysit, weed
your garden, paint your house or do your dishes in exchange. :-) We
will have our own food and one tent.
